Award.AwardTitle: II-NEW: Shelob - A Heterogeneous Computing Platform to Enable Transformation of Computational Research and Education in the State of Louisiana

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Project Shelob is a major effort to support the computational science research, education and training requirements of investigators using modern high performance computing systems equipped with graphical processing units, or GPUs. GPUs are nearly identical to the high-end graphics cards found in personal computers dedicated to gaming applications. The same capabilities that support games with highly realistic real-time animations can be adapted to vastly improve the speed of getting answers on complex science problems. This comes at a cost, however, as the programming becomes more difficult, a burden considering that programming modern parallel computing systems is already a difficult task. The Shelob system provides a dedicated platform to allow experimenting on a production grade system, allowing new methods to be worked out, and providing a platform that can be used for teaching which does not interrupt the critical workflow on other research production systems.
The Shelob system is a compute cluster that allows for parallel programming using distributed memory methods, and adds the ability for nodes to incorporate GPU processing. Such heterogeneous systems require programmers to understand both conventional message-passing (i.e. MPI) programming methods, and the methods specific to GPU programming. The only way researchers can determine how to mix the methods for best performance is to have system-level access to modify and adjust settings as necessary.
There are high expectations for Shelob, not the least of which is instilling excitement in high school and undergraduate students over the possibilities presented for work and research in high performance computing. Programs such as Research Experiences for Undergraduates and the Beowulf Bootcamp, provide unique opportunities to students. Multi-institutional research groups, such as Cactus and Pluto, hope to develop easier ways to make use of the power promised by the Shelob system hardware. Other groups, such as the Louisiana-wide LA-SiGMA project, hope to develop the next generation of codes to support material science research and the development of novel materials for industrial applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Shelob has provided a dedicated platform to a production grade system with graphical processing unit (GPU) acceleration. While GPUs are essential for achieving high performance within power constraints, they are difficult to program. Project Shelob was an important tool for education, training, and research focused on making GPU systems easier to use.
Among the projects that published research based on studies conducted using Shelob were:
   The Louisiana Alliance for Simulation-Guided Materials Applications (LA-SiGMA) developed new software tools to assist the design of novel materials for electronic, energy, and biomolecular applications. They provide important benefits to science and medicine such as:

  • Electronic Materials - development of multiscale methods for strongly correlated electronic and magnetic systems; studies of correlated organic, ferroelectric, and superconducting materials.
  • Energy Materials - study of electro-chemical cells and capacitors that store and deliver electrical energy, advanced materials for highly efficient and long-lasting batteries and catalytic reactions for fuel generation.
  • Biomolecular Materials - development of novel biomolecular material systems for the encapsulation, delivery, and release of therapeutics to targeted tissues.
  • GeauxDock, which provides a platform for accelerated drug discovery through computer simulation.
  • See http://lasigma.loni.org/

   The LSU Geometric and Visual Computing Lab investigated methods of facilitating computation involving large-scale geometric data processing and finite element mesh generation. Both areas impact scientific computing that requires numerical finite element simulation or analysis. See https://gvc.cct.lsu.edu/
   The Pluto compiler is a source-to-source transformation system that can generate code for general purpose multicore systems as well as for GPUs, starting from C source with a few added directives. It is being enhanced to handle heterogeneous environments with multiple GPUs. See http://pluto-compiler.sourceforge.net/
   The Ste||ar Group is developing HPX (High Performance ParalleX) , a general purpose C++ runtime system for parallel and distributed applications of any scale. One sub-effort was HPXCL, a scalable OpenCL API for distributed systems, based on HPX, to address the programming burden of rising numbers of OpenCL programmable devices on modern high performance computing clusters. See http://stellar.cct.lsu.edu/projects/hpx/
   The Chemora project supports the automatic generation of well-tuned codes for accelerated computing cluster simulations of systems described by partial differential equations. The code is dynamically compiled based on a model-driven auto-tuner. This tool will accelerate simulations of diverse systems such as colliding black holes and water waves. See https://chemoracode.org/
   Shelob provided valuable support for education and outreach. Five graduate students from diverse ethnic backgrounds obtained their Ph.D.'s based on research they conducted using this resource. It was also used for training and workshops by the above groups to bring the results of their work to students and researchers in their respective scientific communities.
  Shelob will continue to operate, receiving routine maintenance from the support team at LSU HPC. Despite the completion of the grant, therefore, the benefits of this research tool will continue to accrue, providing additional value for the NSF dollars already spent on its creation and support.
